content:
• Monday, December 21, 2015
  • NTI

    Western Refining reaches deal to buy rest of Northern Tier Energy

    • Northern Tier Energy (NYSE:NTI)Â +9.1% AH after Western Refining (NYSE:WNR) agrees to acquire the ~62% of the company it does not already own in a revised offer that values NTI at $2.43B.
    • NTI unitholders will now receive $15/share in cash and 0.2986 of a share of WNR for each unit held; in October, WNR offered $17.50/share in cash and 0.2266 of a share for each NTI unit.
    • The companies say the merger will result in a diversified refining asset base with three top tier refineries that have direct pipeline access to advantaged crude oil basins, and that the deal includes increased flexibility to sell NTI traditional logistics assets to Western Refining Logistics (NYSE:WNRL).
     
     
     
     
    | 5:47 PM | 50 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: AMID +2.8%. SYT +2.0%. MDCO +2.0%. XIV +1.9%. SNY +1.8%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: SCS -20.0%. TVIX -4.0%. VIIX -2.2%. TS -2.2%. BP -1.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 5 Comments
  • AMID

    American Midstream wins ArcLight purchase of up to $75M in stock

    • American Midstream Partners (AMID +25.8%) skyrockets after investment firm ArcLight Capital Partners said it may buy up to $75M of its shares.
    • ArcLight, which may begin buying shares as early as tomorrow, says it is making the financial commitment because AMID's current unit price undervalues the assets of the company.
    • Wunderlich's Jeff Birnbaum rates AMIND a Buy and says that not only does the purchase plan increase the value per unit, but it is an important show of support from AMID’s general partner given the tough times in the industry.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM | 5 Comments
  • CJ

    C&J Energy started at Neutral by Credit Suisse on EBITDA concerns

    • C&J Energy (CJES -7.3%) is initiated with a Neutral rating with a $5.50 price target at Credit Suisse, which says it is concerned about C&J’s EBITDA generation ability in 2016, its debt covenants and market overcapacity, which is expected to persist into or even through 2017.
    • C&J bought the completion and production services business from Nabors Industries earlier this year, and Credit Suisse says the debt resulting from the deal is one of the reasons for concern regarding C&J’s 2016 EBITDA.
    • Although some improvement is expected in activity in 2017, the firm sees little pricing improvement at least for the next six quarters, along with little improvement in the overall market conditions for at least the next six months.
    • Given the company’s debt-to-cap ratio of 54% and nearly 100% exposure to the U.S. spot market, the firm calls C&J "the epitome of [oilfield services] beta leverage both operationally and financially.”
     
     
     
     
    | 3:45 PM
  • GLUU

    Glu Mobile drops near 20% to hit new 52-week low

    • Glu Mobile (GLUU -19.7%) has spent the afternoon hovering around its new 52-week low, trading at more than triple average volume.
    • Shares have declined 66% from May 4 to set the new low of $2.30 today.
    • An article by SA contributor Chris Lau lays out risks tied to the launch of Glu's latest celebrity-oriented game, Katy Perry Pop -- just out last Thursday, a day where the stock reversed gains to fall more than 5%.
    • The company slid 12% after cutting its guidance in Q3 earnings, and Lau notes that despite forecasting lower growth, the firm issued $5.8M in bonuses -- that against $8.5M in earnings.
    • Users are reporting stability issues with Katy Perry Pop as well, and the game may have excessive in-app costs to get credits to play, he suggests.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:15 PM | 26 Comments
  • CMG

    Chipotle hit again by E. coli report

    • The CDC says it's investigating food sickness complaints from Chipotle (CMG -2.8%) stores in Kansas, North Dakota, and Oklahoma that may be linked to a rare form of the E. coli strain.
    • The 5 illnesses, reported between November 18 and November 26, have not been part of any of the prior CDCÂ Chipotle tallies.
    • Shares of Chipotle were down as much as 6%, but have recovered a bit.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:05 PM | 52 Comments
  • SCCO

    Peru sees 65% copper output surge in 2016, but Tia Maria project still stalled

    • Peru's energy and mines minister says the country's copper output should jump 65% in 2016 to ~2.5M metric tons after the massive Las Bambas project starts operations in February.
    • Ongoing talks in communities where protests against Las Bambas turned deadly in September have been positive recently and have not held up the $7.4B project; the mine should produce 250K-300K metric tons of copper in 2016.
    • But still-strong local opposition to Southern Copper's (SCCO -1.7%) $1.4B Tia Maria project likely prevent the government from issuing a construction permit for the stalled project, the minister says.
    • ETFs: JJC, CPER, CUPM
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 5 Comments
  • FARO

    FARO +6.2%; Needham upgrades, cites valuation and job cuts

    • Noting shares are down over 50% YTD and over 20% since the company posted a Q3 miss and announced CEO Jay Freeland is stepping down, Needham's James Ricchiuti has upgraded FARO Technologies to Buy. His target is $37.
    • Ricchiuti: "We upgrade the stock for 2 main reasons. First, we believe cost-reduction actions FARO announced after Q3 have provided upside to our 2016 estimates, even if revs don’t show a meaningful recovery. Second, while FARO shares are up 18% from their lows in early Nov., the shares are near historical trough valuations going back 5 yrs. While we see no clear evidence yet of meaningful improvement in FARO’s fundamentals, we view the risk-reward opportunity as attractive, with FARO trading at less than 0.9x [estimated 2016 EV/sales]"
    • Two weeks ago: FARO names chairman its interim CEO
     
     
     
     
    | 2:52 PM
  • PAA

    Plains All American downgraded at Oppenheimer, which sees few good options

    • Plains All American Pipeline (PAA +3.9%) is higher despite receiving a downgrade to Perform from Outperform at Oppenheimer, which believes PAA appears has few attractive options for 2016 and that more clarity is required about its plan of action.
    • The firm expects PAA to need equity worth about $1B in 2016 to sustain leverage of 4.5x, but "with an all-in cost of equity greater than 20%, the common equity market is effectively closed" to PAA, thus requiring "non-traditional methods to secure its 2016 business plan."
    • Although PAA's current stock valuation appears to already include some expectations of a distribution cut, Oppenheimer says it needs more clarity regarding the solution the company chooses.
    • Oppenheimer believes the energy infrastructure operating environment is not nearly as bad as the market makes it seem, but says the one company meriting concern is PAA.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:45 PM | 11 Comments
  • FOX

    Beyond 'Star Wars': Chipmunks, sisters take box-office scraps

    • While other films were a little harder to locate amid a record-breaking weekend at home and abroad for Star Wars, there were still box-office scraps to be fought over, and Chipmunks got most of them.
    • The makers of Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (FOX -0.7%, FOXA -0.4%) deliberately aimed for a set of moviegoers who might be younger than Star Wars' PG-13 rating, and took in $14.4M for the No. 2 spot.
    • Meanwhile, Universal's (CMCSA -0.2%) inexpensive comedy Sisters (a film reuniting Tina Fey and Amy Poehler) drew $13.4M for the No. 3 position.
    • The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2 (LGF +0.1%) was No. 4 with $5.6M and Creed (TWX -0.5%) No. 5 with $5.1M. Mockingjay has a five-week domestic total of $254.4M, while Creed has grossed $87.9M in four weeks. Pixar's The Good Dinosaur (DIS -1.5%) drew $4.2M to total $96.6M in its fourth week.
    • While many films dodged Star Wars' juggernaut release, next Christmas weekend is more crowded, with a number of new releases elbowing in for some holiday dollars alongside some expansions of award contenders from limited coastal releases.
    • Previously: Mixed reaction from exhibitor stocks to Star Wars opening (Dec. 21 2015)
    • Previously: 'Star Wars' has $238M opening for the ages (Dec. 20 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:40 PM | 5 Comments
  • WFREF

    Long Run Exploration to be bought by Chinese investors in $770M deal

    • Long Run Exploration (OTCPK:WFREF +114.6%) agrees to be acquired by an unnamed group of Chinese investors in a deal worth ~$770M, or $0.52/share, a 215% premium to its Friday closing price in Toronto; the deal includes the assumption of all outstanding debt.
    • Long Run says it canceled a financing deal reached last month in favor of an outright sale of the company as oil prices deteriorated.
    • The company has been struggling to service its debt and reported a net earnings loss of $305M in Q3.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:26 PM | 3 Comments
  • GPRK

    GeoPark to sell Colombian crude oil to Trafigura in $100M deal

    • GeoPark (GPRK +9.1%) is up sharply after announcing an offtake and prepayment agreement with commodity trader and logistics company Trafigura, which will provide GPRK with up to $100M in funding through prepaid future oil sales over a 30-month contract period.
    • The offtake agreement allows for GPRK to sell and deliver a portion of its Colombian crude oil production to Trafigura at future spot market prices, net of transportation costs, helping improve working capital as well as reducing its transportation and logistics costs and reducing risk.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:13 PM
  • SKBI

    Skystar Bio delisted from Nasdaq; shares off 33%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Skystar Bio-Pharmaceutical (NASDAQ:SKBI)Â dropsÂ 33%Â on increased volume in response to the news that it has been delisted from the Nasdaq effective today.
    • The company received a delinquency notice in late October due to its failure to file its 2014 10-K and 10-Qs for the first two quarters of this year.
    • Previously: Skystar Bio's failure to file financial reports gets response from Nasdaq; shares off 20% (Oct. 26)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:08 PM | 3 Comments
  • MNGA

    MagneGas -29% after negative report on Seeking Alpha

    • MagneGas shares (MNGA -29.6%) are slammed by nearly a third following a negative report on Seeking Alpha by The Pump Stopper, which calls the company is an "imploding paid stock promotion shell" with an immediate 92% downside risk.
    • The article says MNGA's business partners are "non-existent, defunct or unviable" and that the company's auditor was barred by the SEC for falsified and backdated audit documents.
    • In response, MNGA notes the article was written by an anonymous short seller which contains "multiple instances of materially false and misleading information," and says it is "exploring all available legal options."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:03 PM | 44 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: ITUS +41%. AMID +39%. NTWK +36%. AVEO +29%. NBY +28%. OCRX +27%. CAPN +22%. BSI +21%. ATNM +17%. AUO +17%.
    • Losers: SKBI -33%. MNGA -30%. CNV -20%. LITB -20%. GLUU -20%. IMN -17%. AAC -16%. SGY -15%. OTC:INVT -15%. TRCH -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 3 Comments
  • SPIL

    Siliconware promises to weigh ASE's latest offer; shares rise

    • Siliconware (SPIL +2.5%) "will assess" Taiwanese chip packaging/testing peer ASE's (ASX +1.6%) latest offer for the company, an NT$55/share all-cash bid announced last week.
    • Siliconware is still trading NT$4 below ASE's offer price in Taipei. In August, ASE offered NT$45/share for Siliconware, while stating it would buy up to 25% of Siliconware's shares on its own.
    • Since then, Siliconware has sold large stakes to contract manufacturer Foxconn (Hon Hai Precision) and China's state-controlled Tsinghua Unigroup.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:33 PM | 1 Comment
  • IMAX

    Mixed reaction from exhibitor stocks to Star Wars opening

    • IMAX (IMAX -3%) is down on heavy volume even after the box office numbers for Star Wars flew past estimates for the opening weekend.
    • The company averaged $77K per screen during the period which is the best mark it has ever seen for a movie debut.
    • Quick analysis off the slide is that buy-and-hold investors will see the Star Wars boost down the road when earnings are reported, but that options traders are taking it to those looking to cash in off the box office trade (see IMAXÂ options chain). Or perhaps put another way by Yoda: "Fear is the path to the dark side."
    • AMC Entertainment (AMC -2.6%) and Regal Entertainment (RGC -1.1%) are also disappointing investors today, while Carmike Cinemas (CKEC +0.7%) and Reading International (RDI +0.4%) are higher.
    • Previously: 'Star Wars' has $238M opening for the ages (Dec. 20 2015)
    • Previously: IMAX higher after blowout Star Wars numbers (Dec. 21 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:25 PM | 10 Comments
  • INTC

    Chinese regulators approve Intel-Altera deal; closing expected soon

    • China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) has signed off on Intel's (INTC - unchanged) purchase of Altera (ALTR +2%), thus providing the final regulatory clearance needed for the $16.7B ($54/share) all-cash deal to go through. (8-K filing)
    • The acquisition is now expected to close "on or about" Dec. 28. Altera has risen to within $0.09 of Intel's buyout price.
    • Two months ago: EU regulators approve Intel/Altera deal
     
     
     
     
    | 11:52 AM | 10 Comments
  • ENLC

    EnLink Midstream downgraded, TC Pipelines upgraded at BofA/Merrill

    • EnLink Midstream (ENLC -7.4%) is downgraded to Neutral from Buy with an $18 price target, reduced from $28, at BofA/Merrill, which forecasts flat distributions through 2017 at ENLC and EnLink Midstream Partners (ENLK +2.4%), believing management will be prudent in building coverage instead of prioritizing distribution growth.
    • The firm notes the $1.5B acquisition of Tall Oak Midstream is expected to generate $80M in EBITDA 2016 and expanding to $300M by 2018, as EnLink deploys $650M in capex over three years.
    • Meanwhile, BofA upgrades TC Pipelines (TCP +2.8) to Buy from Underperform with a $50 price target, citing a fee-based cash flow profile, which “should bode well in a persistent MLP environment of high volatility, capital market concerns, and focus on leverage.”
     
     
     
     
    | 11:46 AM
  • WMC

    Western Asset Mortgage gives back gains and more

    • The stock posted a nice gain on Friday after the company shaved just $0.02 off of its quarterly dividend. Annualized, the new $0.58 payout still amounts to a whopping near-20% yield (based on Thursday's close).
    • Writing on Seeking Alpha over the weekend, ColoradoWealthManagementFund notes estimated Nov. 30 book value of $12.91 was down from $13.26 at the end of Q3. Further, the 6.7% discount to book the stock is trading at is likely far too slim compared to most of the rest of the sector selling for well into double-digit discounts to book.
    • Yes, the dividend was better-than-hoped, but it was the result of higher leverage which also ended up dinging book value, argues the author.
    • WMC -7.5% to $11.28.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:25 AM | 2 Comments
  • RICE

    Rice Energy gets $500M investment, shares +9%

    • Rice Energy (RICE +8.9%) surges on news that an infrastructure fund agreed to invest up to $500M in Rice Midstream Partners (RMP +0.2%), a move that will help fund the company's 2016 capital spending plans.
    • The unspecified fund will get preferred equity in the MLP for its pipeline assets, while a new wholly owned subsidiary called GP Holdings will have the common units, subordinated units and incentive distribution rights in RMLP.
    • Rice says it will use $375M from the deal to fund its drilling in the Marcellus and Utica shales as well as pay off Rice Midstream Holdings' revolving credit facility.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:22 AM
  • SPWR

    Solar stocks add to ITC-fueled gains; Morgan Stanley hikes targets

    • The Guggenheim Solar ETF (TAN +2.1%) is now up 11% since Congress agreed six days ago to a budget compromise (officially passed on Friday) that involved extending the solar investment tax credit (ITC) and wind production tax credit (PTC). Today's gains come with the Nasdaq up 0.6%.
    • U.S. solar stocks naturally continue headlining the list of gainers. The list includes SunPower (SPWR +3.4%), First Solar (FSLR +3.3%), Sunrun (RUN +6.9%), Enphase (ENPH +8%), 8point3 Energy (CAFD +4.1%), RGS Energy (RGSE +19.6%), and Solar3D (SLTD +4.5%).
    • Other winners include JinkoSolar (JKS +4.7%), ReneSola (SOL +8%), Yingli (YGE +3.5%), China Sunergy (CSUN +4.2%), TerraForm Global (GLBL +3.2%), and SolarEdge (SEDG +3.2%), the last of which depends heavily on the U.S. residential market.
    • Citing (what else?) the tax credit extensions, Morgan Stanley's Stephen Byrd has respectively hiked his SolarCity (SCTY -0.3%), First Solar, SunPower, and Sunrun targets by $18, $2, $2, and $5 to $104, $70, $43, and $28. Bernstein and KeyBanc respectively upgraded SolarCity and Sunrun last Thursday.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:11 AM | 5 Comments
  • CC

    Chemours sinks following upward climb

    • Chemours (CC -10.2%) gives back all of Friday's gains, which saw the stock soar after announcing global price increases.
    • Previously: TiO2 players surge following Chemours price hike (Dec. 18 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:59 AM | 6 Comments
  • JNPR

    Juniper slumps as FBI probes firewall security breach

    • The FBI is investigating potential spying by a foreign government through a backdoor (made possible by the placement of "unauthorized" OS source code) within firewalls sold by Juniper's (JNPR -4.1%) NetScreen security hardware unit.
    • Officials talking with CNN place China and Russia at the top of their suspect list - one describes the breach as akin to "stealing a master key to get into any government building." Juniper has issued an emergency security patch to remove the backdoor.
    • Security pros are at a loss to figure out how hackers will able to modify Juniper's source code without the company knowing for years. An exec at security software firm Rapid7: "I suspect that this incident will trigger internal security audits across the industry and cause Juniper to drastically change their code review process."
    • Juniper's security product revenue, pressured by the growth of Palo Alto Networks and other upstarts, fell 1% Y/Y in Q3 to $119.6M, and accounted for 13% of total product revenue.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:34 AM
  • AVEO

    AVEO inks license deal for tivozanib in Europe for kidney cancer; shares up 31%

    • Nano cap AVEO Pharmaceuticals (AVEO +31.1%) enters into an exclusive license agreement with EUSA Pharma for the European rights to lead product candidate tivozanib for the treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The deal also includes South Africa and additional countries in South America as well as additional potential indications.
    • Under the terms of the agreement, AVEO will receive an upfront payment of $2.5M, up to $394M in milestones and tiered royalties ranging from low double-digit to mid-20%. A portion of the milestones and royalties will be payable to Kyowa Hakko Kirin under a sublicensing deal.
    • EUSA plans to submit a Marketing Authorization Application (MAA) for tivozanib for the first-line treatment of advanced RCC in Q1.
    • Tivozanib is an oral, once-daily, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI). It is designed to optimize VEGF blockade while minimizing toxic side effects.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:29 AM
  • DLNG

    Dynagas buys LNG carrier, to recommend 4%-6% distribution increase

    • Dynagas LNGÂ Partners (DLNG +15.1%) surges following late Friday's announced agreement with Dynagas Holding to purchase the entity that owns and operates the Lena River, a 155K cm ice class liquefied natural gas carrier, and the related time charter contract with Gazprom (OTCPK:OGZPY), for $240M.
    • Following the completion of the Lena River acquisition, DLNG says it will recommend to its board a 4%-6% increase in its quarterly distribution to $0.439-$0.448 ($1.76-$1.79 annualized), effective for the March quarter.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:21 AM | 5 Comments
  • HOPE

    BBCN Bancorp up 7% after upgrade

    • BBCN (BBCN +7.3%) earlier this month spurned an offer from Hanmi Financial, instead deciding to merge with Wilshire Bancorp (WIBC +7.9%). The joining of the two Korean-American banks would crete the 7th-largest publicly-traded bank HQ'd in California.
    • Hanmi Financial late last week withdrew its offer.
    • BBCN has given up plenty of ground since the Wilshire announcement, but gets a chunk of that back today after an upgrade to Outperform from KBW.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:10 AM
  • AAXN

    Taser on the move

    • Taser (TASR +6.2%) climbs in early trade after announcing multiple orders of its next generation Smart Weapons.
    • The orders were received and are expected to ship in the fourth quarter.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:09 AM | 11 Comments
  • TRGP

    Targa Resources, Targa Resources Partners downgraded at Credit Suisse

    • Targa Resources (TRGP -7.8%) and Targa Resources Partners (NGLS -8.9%) are downgraded (I, II) to Underperform from Outperform at Credit Suisse, citing dividend cut pressures.
    • On TRGP, Credit Suisse says it sees distribution coverage below 1x and leverage above 6x and sees "no way out of the woods" without a "substantial" dividend cut; the firm models an 80% dividend cut in 2016 with zero growth until 2020, when leverage finally drops below 3.5x.
    • The firm cuts its stock price targets to $36 from $79 on TRGP and to $22 from $49 for NGLS.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:06 AM | 9 Comments
  • FIT

    Fitbit gains following bullish pre-Christmas Pac Crest, Piper notes

    • Pac Crest's Brad Erickson says checks indicate sales of Fitbit's (FIT +2.4%) hardware have been "exploding" since a soft Black Friday, with inventories below 10 days again and many Best Buys struggling to keep the Charge HR band ($150 MSRP) in stock. "30% of stores we talked to have seen temporary sell-outs and we think Fitbit's share remains dominant, if not improving, thus far in Q4."
    • Erickson is also encouraged by discounting from the likes of Garmin and Apple, and believes online sales could be strong. "While bears will continue to latch on to the likely longer-term headwinds for the consumer business, we note that corporate wellness is a huge and growing opportunity for which Fitbit is in the lead, and this remains heavily discounted by most investors we talk to."
    • He thinks shares have been pressured by reports a second-gen Apple Watch will be unveiled in March, and consider the drop a buying opportunity. Shares closed on Friday just $1.27 above a post-IPO low of $26.46.
    • Meanwhile, Piper's Erinn Murphy reports seeing "increased promotional activity" this holiday season relative to past years, but adds Fitbit's discounting has been less than that of both fitness tracker peers and consumer electronics firms in general.
    • She adds 7 of the top 10 spots in Amazon's sports/fitness bestseller rankings are claimed by Fitbit (ed: Fitbit has the top 5 as of this moment). "We continue to be buyers of FIT and have an upward bias to our Q4 estimate. We favor the set up on FIT over the next few months in particular."
     
     
     
     
    | 10:04 AM | 13 Comments
  • AVGO

    Avago higher following RBC Top Pick call, upbeat EPS growth forecast

    • Forecasting strong EPS growth following the closing of the Broadcom deal, RBC's Amit Daryanani has added Avago (AVGO +1.6) to his firm's Top Pick list, and hiked his target by $15 to $170.
    • Daryanani: "Our bullish bias is predicated on our belief that AVGO will expand EPS from $9.24 in CY15E to [more than] $16.00 by CY18E driven by multiple levers – BRCM integration, asset divestures, RF ramp-up, cost containment and potential deleveraging ... we estimate [less than 30%] of future EPS growth is predicated on organic revenue dynamics and 70%+ is driven by AVGO’s ability to curtail costs, optimize the portfolio, and further deleveraging."
    • He forecasts $6B/year in free cash flow by 2018, which in turn is expected to provide Avago with ample liquidity to deleverage or make more acquisitions. "While we are cognizant that the markets (and semiconductors specifically) are observing softer demand trends, in our view AVGO has the potential to offset soft demand trends via self-help levers at its disposal."
    • Shares are three weeks removed from jumping in response to an FQ4 EPS beat (driven by margin strength) and better-than-feared FQ1 guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:37 AM | 1 Comment

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers as of 9:10 am

    • Gainers: NTWK +33%. AVEO +25%. GENE +14%. WMIH +8%. SBGL +8%. GGB +7%. ERIC +7%. UUUU +6%. RWLK +6%.
    • Losers: GBSN -11%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:18 AM | 1 Comment
  • OKE

    ONEOK says it will maintain distribution, sees coverage of 1x of better

    • ONEOKÂ (OKE, OKS) +2.2% premarket after saying it expects to sustain its current distribution and achieve distribution coverage of 1x or better in 2016, and remains committed to maintaining its investment-grade credit ratings.
    • OKE also says it does not expect to access public equity markets in 2016 and well into 2017.
    • OKE foresees $675M in cash available for dividends at 1.3x coverage ratio, as well as FY 2016 adjusted EBITDA of $$1.88Bn, distributable cash flow of $1.39B, growth capex of $460M, and maintenance capex of $140M.
    • "Our commodity price outlook remains cautious for 2016. However, we expect the partnership's 2016 earnings to increase compared with 2015 guidance, primarily from volume and fee-based margin increases, resulting in increased distributable cash flow,"Â OKE says.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:55 AM | 11 Comments
  • PBY-OLD

    Pep Boys higher after receiving new Icahn offer

    • Pep Boys (NYSE:PBY-OLD) announces that it considers a $16.50 offer received Friday evening from Icahn Enterprises as superior to a previous bid from Bridgestone.
    • PBY +4.7% premarket to $16.50.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:48 AM | 2 Comments
  • EMR

    Orders fall as Emerson Electric

    • Emerson Electric (NYSE:EMR) drops 1.3% premarket after the company's trailing three-month orders fell 13% on low oil prices, reduced levels of industrial capital spending, demand weakness in emerging markets, and strength of the U.S. dollar.
    • Reported sales for the first quarter are anticipated to decrease approximately 17%, while reported earnings per share are expected to be approximately $0.50.
    • SEC Form 8-K
     
     
     
     
    | 8:48 AM | 8 Comments
  • HAS

    Hasbro on watch after Star Wars shines

    • Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) is higher in early trading with the company's contract with Disney looking a little bit more significant after Star Wars: The Force Awakens smashes box office records.
    • Star Wars toys well have sold well since Black Friday, according to retail channel checks.
    • Previously: 'Star Wars' has $238M opening for the ages (Dec. 20 2015)
    • HASÂ +1.63% premarket to $66.90.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:28 AM | 3 Comments
  • BA

    Is Boeing headed for takeoff or landing?

    • Boeing (NYSE:BA) shares were all over the place last week, with fresh news each day triggering price moves in each direction.
    • The week began with a dividend and buyback boost and ended with a downgrade, with aircraft sale announcements, new concerns about pricing and more analyst comments than one could count in between.
    • Boeing - buy, hold or sell?
    • BAÂ +1.1% premarket
    • Previously: Boeing -4% as concerns mount over aircraft demand (Dec. 18 2015)
    • Previously: Boeing downgraded at Wells Fargo (Dec. 18 2015)
    • Previously: Boeing slips after Delta says it is buying a used 777 for $7.7M (Dec. 17 2015)
    • Previously: China Southern Airlines orders Boeing jets worth $10B (Dec. 17 2015)
    • Previously: Delta to buy up to 40 jets in plan shelved after union vote (Dec. 16 2015)
    • Previously: Boeing bulls and bears each present strong cases, but Canaccord tilts bullish (Dec. 15 2015)
    • Previously: Boeing raises buyback program to $14B, raises dividend 20% (Dec. 14 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:36 AM | 4 Comments
